articles.headline: U.S. Appears to Be Waiting to Act on Israeli Airstrikes
articles.snippet: The plan is for Israel to hit Lebanon for about another week, followed by a visit by Condoleezza Rice to establish a buffer zone, officials said.
articles.abstract: The plan is for Israel to hit Lebanon for about another week, followed by a visit by Condoleezza Rice to establish a buffer zone, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 18 — The outlines of an American-Israeli consensus began to emerge on Tuesday in which Israel would continue to bombard Lebanon for about another week to degrade the capabilities of the Hezbollah militia, officials of the two countries said.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Disney Studio to Be Revamped, With 650 Jobs Cut
articles.snippet: Nina Jacobson, who has been head of live-action production at Walt Disney Studios, will leave immediately.
articles.abstract: Nina Jacobson, who has been head of live-action production at Walt Disney Studios, will leave immediately.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, July 18 — The Walt Disney Company announced a major revamping of its movie studio on Tuesday, cutting 650 jobs worldwide and replacing some crucial executives.

articles.headline: Immigration Enforcement Benefits Prison Firms
articles.snippet: Private  prison operators are jockeying for a bigger piece of the growing business of detaining immigrants.
articles.abstract: Private  prison operators are jockeying for a bigger piece of the growing business of detaining immigrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Bush administration gets tougher on illegal immigration and increases its spending on enforcement, some of the biggest beneficiaries may be the companies that have been building and running private prisons around the country.

articles.headline: Patient Deaths in New Orleans Bring Arrests
articles.snippet: A doctor and two nurses are accused of using lethal injections to kill four patients after Hurricane Katrina.
articles.abstract: A doctor and two nurses are accused of using lethal injections to kill four patients after Hurricane Katrina.
articles.lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La., July 18  A doctor and two nurses were arrested Tuesday after the Louisiana attorney general accused them of using lethal injections to kill four elderly patients in a New Orleans hospital last year in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Shaila Dewan

articles.headline: Iraqi Death Toll Rises Above 100 Per Day, U.N. Says
articles.snippet: June's toll, the highest monthly tally since Baghdad's fall, was underscored by a suicide bombing that killed 53.
articles.abstract: June's toll, the highest monthly tally since Baghdad's fall, was underscored by a suicide bombing that killed 53.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 18 — An average of more than 100 civilians per day were killed in Iraq last month, the United Nations reported Tuesday, registering what appears to be the highest official monthly tally of violent deaths since the fall of Baghdad.

articles.headline: With Israeli Use of Force, Debate Over Proportion
articles.snippet: The asymmetry in the conflict’s death tolls has led to accusations that Israel is guilty of “disproportionate use of force.”
articles.abstract: The asymmetry in the conflict’s death tolls has led to accusations that Israel is guilty of “disproportionate use of force.”
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, July 18 — The asymmetry in the reported death tolls is marked and growing: some 230 Lebanese dead, most of them civilians, to 25 Israeli dead, 13 of them civilians. In Gaza, one Israel soldier has died from his own army’s fire, and 103 Palestinians have been killed, 70 percent of them militants.

articles.headline: Front Page of Journal to Get Ads
articles.snippet: The move could bring in tens of millions of dollars in advertising revenue each year to the newspaper.
articles.abstract: The move could bring in tens of millions of dollars in advertising revenue each year to the newspaper.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal calls it a “jewel box,’’ but readers of its front page will know it by its common name: advertising.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Katharine Q. Seelye

articles.headline: Weak Sales of Text Ads at Yahoo; Shares Dip
articles.snippet: Yahoo reported a delay in a critical project that is meant to increase search revenue by selecting relevant text advertisements.
articles.abstract: Yahoo reported a delay in a critical project that is meant to increase search revenue by selecting relevant text advertisements.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares of Yahoo fell to their lowest level in nearly two years in after-hours trading yesterday as it reported weak revenue from Internet search advertising in the second quarter and a delay in a critical project that is meant to increase search revenue.

articles.headline: U.S. Appears to Be Waiting to Act on Israeli Airstrikes
articles.snippet: The outlines of an American-Israeli consensus began to emerge on Tuesday in which Israel would continue to bombard Lebanon for about another week to degrade the capabilities of the Hezbollah militia, officials of the two countries said.     Then, ...
articles.abstract: The outlines of an American-Israeli consensus began to emerge on Tuesday in which Israel would continue to bombard Lebanon for about another week to degrade the capabilities of the Hezbollah militia, officials of the two countries said.     Then, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice would go to the region and seek to establish a buffer zone in southern Lebanon and perhaps an international force to monitor Lebanon's borders to prevent Hezbollah from obtaining more rockets with which to bombard Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 18 - The outlines of an American-Israeli consensus began to emerge on Tuesday in which Israel would continue to bombard Lebanon for about another week to degrade the capabilities of the Hezbollah militia, officials of the two countries said.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Iraqi Death Toll Rises Above 100 Per Day, U.N. Says
articles.snippet: An average of more than 100 civilians per day were killed in Iraq last month, the United Nations reported Tuesday, registering what appears to be the highest official monthly tally of violent deaths since the fall of Baghdad.     The death toll, d...
articles.abstract: An average of more than 100 civilians per day were killed in Iraq last month, the United Nations reported Tuesday, registering what appears to be the highest official monthly tally of violent deaths since the fall of Baghdad.     The death toll, drawn from Iraqi government agencies, was the most precise measurement of civilian deaths provided by any government organization since the invasion and represented a substantial increase over the figures in daily news media reports.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 18 - An average of more than 100 civilians per day were killed in Iraq last month, the United Nations reported Tuesday, registering what appears to be the highest official monthly tally of violent deaths since the fall of Baghdad.

articles.headline: Immigration Enforcement Benefits Prison Firms
articles.snippet: As the Bush administration gets tougher on illegal immigration and increases its spending on enforcement, some of the biggest beneficiaries may be the companies that have been building and running private prisons around the country.     By the fal...
articles.abstract: As the Bush administration gets tougher on illegal immigration and increases its spending on enforcement, some of the biggest beneficiaries may be the companies that have been building and running private prisons around the country.     By the fall of 2007, the administration expects that about 27,500 immigrants will be in detention each night, an increase of 6,700 over the current number in custody. At the average cost these days of $95 a night, that adds up to an estimated total annual cost of nearly $1 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Bush administration gets tougher on illegal immigration and increases its spending on enforcement, some of the biggest beneficiaries may be the companies that have been building and running private prisons around the country.

articles.headline: Front Page of Journal to Get Ads
articles.snippet: The Wall Street Journal calls it a ''jewel box,'' but readers of its front page will know it by its common name: advertising.      The Journal confirmed today the speculation that it would open its front page to advertisers, probably in September,...
articles.abstract: The Wall Street Journal calls it a ''jewel box,'' but readers of its front page will know it by its common name: advertising.      The Journal confirmed today the speculation that it would open its front page to advertisers, probably in September, a move that could bring in tens of millions of dollars a year in revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal calls it a "jewel box," but readers of its front page will know it by its common name: advertising.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Katharine Q. Seelye

articles.headline: Disney Studio to Be Revamped, With 650 Jobs Cut
articles.snippet: The Walt Disney Company announced a major revamping of its movie studio on Tuesday, cutting 650 jobs worldwide and replacing some crucial executives.     Nina Jacobson, who has been head of live-action production at Walt Disney Studios, including ...
articles.abstract: The Walt Disney Company announced a major revamping of its movie studio on Tuesday, cutting 650 jobs worldwide and replacing some crucial executives.     Nina Jacobson, who has been head of live-action production at Walt Disney Studios, including last year's hit ''The Chronicles of Narnia,'' will leave immediately, the company said. Her departure was not unexpected by many in Hollywood, although its timing was a surprise; many here said she would stay for several months because she had recently renegotiated her contract.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, July 18 - The Walt Disney Company announced a major revamping of its movie studio on Tuesday, cutting 650 jobs worldwide and replacing some crucial executives.

articles.headline: Senate Approves A Stem Cell Bill; Veto Is Expected
articles.snippet: Following two days of often personal debate, the Senate defied a veto threat by President Bush on Tuesday and approved legislation that would expand federal support of medical research using embryonic stem cells.     White House officials said Mr....
articles.abstract: Following two days of often personal debate, the Senate defied a veto threat by President Bush on Tuesday and approved legislation that would expand federal support of medical research using embryonic stem cells.     White House officials said Mr. Bush planned to veto the measure as early as Wednesday, ignoring the substantial support it won from Senate Republicans, including the majority leader, Bill Frist of Tennessee. It would be the first veto of Mr. Bush's presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 18 - Following two days of often personal debate, the Senate defied a veto threat by President Bush on Tuesday and approved legislation that would expand federal support of medical research using embryonic stem cells.

articles.headline: With Israeli Use of Force, Debate Over Proportion
articles.snippet: The asymmetry in the reported death tolls is marked and growing: some 230 Lebanese dead, most of them civilians, to 25 Israeli dead, 13 of them civilians. In Gaza, one Israel soldier has died from his own army's fire, and 103 Palestinians have bee...
articles.abstract: The asymmetry in the reported death tolls is marked and growing: some 230 Lebanese dead, most of them civilians, to 25 Israeli dead, 13 of them civilians. In Gaza, one Israel soldier has died from his own army's fire, and 103 Palestinians have been killed, 70 percent of them militants.      The cold figures, combined with Israeli air attacks on civilian infrastructure like power plants, electricity transformers, airports, bridges, highways and government buildings, have led to accusations by France and the European Union, echoed by some nongovernmental organizations, that Israel is guilty of ''disproportionate use of force'' in the Gaza Strip and Lebanon and of ''collective punishment'' of the civilian populations.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, July 18 - The asymmetry in the reported death tolls is marked and growing: some 230 Lebanese dead, most of them civilians, to 25 Israeli dead, 13 of them civilians. In Gaza, one Israel soldier has died from his own army's fire, and 103 Palestinians have been killed, 70 percent of them militants.

articles.headline: Patient Deaths in New Orleans Bring Arrests
articles.snippet: A doctor and two nurses were arrested Tuesday after the Louisiana attorney general accused them of using lethal injections to kill four elderly patients in a New Orleans hospital last year in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.     Quoting other h...
articles.abstract: A doctor and two nurses were arrested Tuesday after the Louisiana attorney general accused them of using lethal injections to kill four elderly patients in a New Orleans hospital last year in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.     Quoting other hospital staff members, a state affidavit portrayed the doctor, Anna M. Pou, as methodically ordering up a list of patients remaining at the flooded Memorial Medical Center, three days after the storm. Many had already been evacuated from the hospital, which was surrounded by five feet of water and was baking in 100-degree-plus heat. The sickest, however, were still there.
articles.lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La., July 18 - A doctor and two nurses were arrested Tuesday after the Louisiana attorney general accused them of using lethal injections to kill four elderly patients in a New Orleans hospital last year in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Shaila Dewan

articles.headline: Weak Sales of Text Ads at Yahoo; Shares Dip
articles.snippet: Shares of Yahoo fell to their lowest level in nearly two years in after-hours trading yesterday as it reported weak revenue from Internet search advertising in the second quarter and a delay in a critical project that is meant to increase search r...
articles.abstract: Shares of Yahoo fell to their lowest level in nearly two years in after-hours trading yesterday as it reported weak revenue from Internet search advertising in the second quarter and a delay in a critical project that is meant to increase search revenue.     While Yahoo, which runs the world's most popular Internet site, has a booming business selling graphical advertising, it has been struggling to rebuild its search service.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares of Yahoo fell to their lowest level in nearly two years in after-hours trading yesterday as it reported weak revenue from Internet search advertising in the second quarter and a delay in a critical project that is meant to increase search revenue.
